trans-unit.source: Enables you to specify multiple fields for display, per item in an object list.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

Much of the behavior of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>, including support for templated rendering through device template sets and internal pagination, is similar to the behavior of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.List>.

For more information, see the [Introduction to the ObjectList Control](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/527ca783-0ff9-4247-b407-8e58d093faa9) or the [Pagination](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/b4f4c4bc-226b-46ec-ae46-00497a32f4f2) documentation.
Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> class.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Notifies the server control that an element, either XML or HTML, was parsed, and adds the element to the server control's <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.Controls"></xref> property.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
Returns the collection of all fields from the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> class, whether explicit or automatically generated.
The default value is the collection of automatically generated fields.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This collection is available only after data binding.
Unlike the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.Fields%2A> collection, you cannot add or remove items in this collection.
By default, this collection is the set of automatically generated fields.
If any fields are explicitly defined, they are contained after any automatically generated fields.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.IObjectListFieldCollection"></xref> object containing all fields in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref>.
Specifies whether fields must be automatically generated from data.
When enabled, each public property of the data becomes a field of the control.
The default value is `true`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When `true`, the object list handles the fields order in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListFieldCollection> collection.
When `false`, you must specify the order of the fields and set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileListItem.DataItem%2A> property to bind to a data source.
`true` if the fields are automatically generated from data; otherwise, `false`.
Gets or sets the text used for the command to return from the `Details` view (accessed through a softkey or link).
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default text is "Back".
This label is displayed on WAP browsers and in HTML view.
The text used for the command to return from the `Details` view.
Gets the collection of commands in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> object.
Initially, the collection is empty.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The collection of commands in the object list.
Gets or sets the style used for the object list commands.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
If this property is programmatically set, it is not persisted unless the property is set dynamically on each request.
If the property is set declaratively, the property is set on each request.
There is no default.
Since different devices have different requirements for styles.
You may want several <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.DeviceSpecific%2A> settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.CommandStyle%2A> property.
The style used for the object list commands.
Automatically generates fields for the given data.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The specified source of the data.
Notifies server controls to create any child controls in preparation for posting back or rendering.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Creates a list item to contain the object and binds it to the specified object.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Inheriting classes can override this method to provide a different way of creating an item, or can call this method to construct an item.
The list item to bind.
An object list item created from the specified object.
Creates items in an items collection from the specified dataSource parameter.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Inheriting classes can override this method for custom data-binding behavior.
The source from which items in the collection are created.
Constructs the details view for the current item by using the `ItemDetailsTemplate`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called by device adapters when rendering templates.
Returns `true` if the instantiated templates must bind to available data (which usually happens on the first request).
Returns `false` if the templates must not bind to data, and instead rely on view state to have them filled in (which usually happens on subsequent postbacks).
Constructs the list view by building templates.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called by device adapters when rendering templates.
Returns `true` if the instantiated templates must bind to available data (which usually happens on the first request).
Returns `false` if the templates must not bind to data, and instead rely on view state to have them filled in (which usually happens on subsequent postbacks).
Binds a data source to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Gets or sets the data member to extract when data binding to a list data source.
The default value is an empty string ("").
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

This property is only used if the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DataSource%2A> property is of type <xref:System.ComponentModel.IListSource>, rather than of type <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable>.
The data member to extract from the data source when data binding to an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref>.
Gets or sets the data source of the list that is being bound.
The default value is null.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
To bind a data source to a list, you must first use the control's <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DataBind%2A> method to ensure data binding.
The data source can be of type <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable> or of type <xref:System.ComponentModel.IListSource>.
If the data source is of type <xref:System.ComponentModel.IListSource>, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DataMember%2A> field to specify which member to extract.
The data source of the list that is being bound.
Gets or sets the name of the default command.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When set, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> control attempts to render a shortcut to invoke the default command.
In HTML, the default rendering in list view displays the first field as a link to the details view of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>.
When the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DefaultCommand%2A> property is set, clicking the link invokes the default command.
Invoking the default command raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs.CommandName%2A> of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListCommandEventArgs> object is set to the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DefaultCommand%2A> property.
Even if a default command is defined, you should include a command with the same name in the commands collection.

If the control cannot render a graphical element that includes a shortcut for the default command, the default command is still available through the rendering of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> commands collection.
The name of the default command.
Returns the panel that contains a device-specific details view.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The details view has a table that lists each field title and value.
In addition, it lists all the commands associated with an item.
For some devices, this view also contains a link that returns the user to the list view.
A panel that contains a device-specific details view.
the current view is not the details view.
Gets or sets the text used for the menu item that shows the details view.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
If you attempt to set a string that is longer than can be displayed, the default value is displayed.
The default text is "Go".
This label is displayed only on WAP browsers.
The text used for the menu item that shows the details view.
Determines whether the server control contains child controls.
If it does not, it creates child controls.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Use this method to ensure that the templates are instantiated to allow programmatic access to the instantiated contents of a template.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Gets the collection of explicitly defined fields in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListFieldCollection"></xref> class.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

You can add or remove fields in the collection by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListFieldCollection.Add%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListFieldCollection.AddAt%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListFieldCollection.Remove%2A>, and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListFieldCollection.RemoveAt%2A> methods of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListFieldCollection> class.
The collection of explicitly defined fields for the object list control.

Gets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> control has an event handler registered for the appropriate <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
`true` if the object list control has an event handler registered for the appropriate <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand"></xref> event; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the number of items in the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
Occurs when the user selects a command that is associated with an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> item.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

When an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event handler is defined, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> notifies the handler when an item event is generated through user interaction.
When you render an object list by using templates, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event handler is called through the event-bubbling mechanism of ASP.NET.

The event handler is passed an argument of type <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListCommandEventArgs>, which contains information about the source item and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs.CommandName%2A> property of the control that generated the event.
This allows you to render a single item with multiple associated interactions.
On default rendering, the control renders each of the commands defined for the object list as a link.

When the user clicks a link, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event handler is called with an argument of type <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListCommandEventArgs>, which contains information about the source item.
The value in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs.CommandName%2A> property is the name of the command that the user invoked.
Occurs when an item in an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> is bound to data.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When an item in an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> is created and data-bound, this event handler sets the properties of the list item from arbitrary expressions.
An item in an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> control is of type <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListItem>.
Gets the collection of items in an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListItemCollection"></xref> list.
The default value is an empty collection.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
You can inspect the items in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListItemCollection> collection, but you cannot modify the collection.
The collection of items in the object list.
Occurs when a user selects an item from a list view.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This event is called before the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ShowItemCommands> event is called.
Gets or sets a value (the name or data field) that identifies the field to use as a label for each item.
The default value is empty, which causes the first field in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.AllFields"></xref> collection to be used as a label for each item.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is ignored if the list view is shown as a table.
The name or data field that identifies the field to use as a label for each item.

Gets the index in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.AllFields"></xref> collection of the field that has been set by the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.LabelField"></xref> property.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.LabelField%2A> property has not been set, <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.LabelFieldIndex%2A> returns zero.
The index within the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.AllFields"></xref> collection of the field that is used as the label.
The default value is zero.
Gets or sets the style used for the header label.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Setting this property in code is not persisted between requests, so if you want the style to be consistently set, you must set the property on each request.
If the property is set declaratively, the property is persisted between requests.
In addition, setting the property declaratively allows you to use a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.DeviceSpecific>/`Choice` structure to set the property for various devices.
The style used for the header label.
Loads private view state.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
Restores view-state information from a previous page request that was saved by the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.SaveViewState"></xref> method.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
Gets or sets the text string used for the `More` link used on HTML browsers to navigate to the details view.
The default is `More` or the localized equivalent.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The `More` link is rendered to provide a link from the `ListView` of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> to the `DetailsView` of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>.
The following conditions must be met for the `More` link to be rendered:
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DefaultCommand%2A> property must be set.
There must be additional fields or commands to be rendered in the details view.
The default rendering of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> displays the first field in the `ListView` as a link to the `DetailsView` page.
Setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DefaultCommand%2A> property overrides this link and causes it to raise the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event.
As a result, the `More` link is rendered to provide a link to the `DetailsView`.
This property is not the same as the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DetailsCommandText%2A> property, which is used on WAP browsers.
The text string used for the `More` link used on HTML browsers to navigate to the details view.
Determines whether the event for the server control is passed up the page's UI server control hierarchy.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
None.
None.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.DataBinding"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This method notifies a server control to perform any logic for binding data that is associated with it.
If you want to handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.DataBinding> event, you should override this event-handling method.
This ensures that all delegates attached to the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.DataBinding> event are invoked.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> object that contains the event data.
the data source provided no data to bind to.
Called when a list item generates an event as a result of user interaction.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event.
Inheriting classes can override this method to perform other tasks.
An object (defined by <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListCommandEventArgs"></xref>) that contains event data.
Called when a list item is data bound.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemDataBind> event.
Inheriting classes can override this method to perform other tasks.
An object (defined by <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListDataBindEventArgs"></xref>) that contains event data.
Called after the user selects an item.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemSelect> event.
Inheriting classes can override this method to retrieve the required data.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListSelectEventArgs"></xref> object that contains event data.
Called when the control is custom paginated and needs more data.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.PreRender"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
Called prior to showing the set of commands for a list item.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ShowItemCommands> event.
Inheriting classes can override this method to perform other tasks.
An object defined by an <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> object that contains event data.

Prepares the set of commands for a specified item prior to showing it, by calling any event handlers that might be set on the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ShowItemCommands"></xref> event.
Called internally by ASP.NET.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
You would use this method only when writing new device adapters.
The index reference for the item.
Called to raise an event for the default command associated with the specified item.
Called internally by the ASP.NET.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This method can be used by adapters.
The index reference for the item.
Notifies the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> object of a postback event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> that represents an optional event argument to be passed to the event handler.
Saves any private view-state changes that have occurred since the page was loaded from persistence.
If no changes were made, this method returns `null` (`Nothing` in Visual Basic).
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
Saves any server control view-state changes that have occurred since the time the page was posted back to the server.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
None.
Returns the index of the selected item.
The default value is `-1`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Multiple selections are not supported.
Set this property to `-1` to clear the selection.
The index of the selected item.

an attempt to clear this property was made while the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ViewMode"></xref> property was not set to <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.List"></xref>.
the value is less than zero or larger than or equal to the number of items in the list.
Returns the selected item, or `null` if there is no selection.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Multiple selections are not supported.
The selected item, or `null` if there is no selection.
Tests whether an item in an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> is selected.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Specifies the item to test.
Contains `true` if more than one item can be selected.
Otherwise, it contains `false`.
`true` if item is selected; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the text used for the command to select more items in an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The text used for the command to select more items in an object list.
Occurs before the commands related to an item in an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> are shown.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The event argument contains a reference to the item and to the collection of commands.
An event handler can customize the collection according to the item.
Applications can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ShowItemCommands> event to provide functionality equivalent to item-specific shortcut menus.
Changes made to the collection of commands during this event are not persisted.
This event is called after the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemSelect> event is called.
You can use this event to perform other tasks before showing the detail view.
You can add, remove, or rearrange fields, depending on the item selected in the list view.

Gets an array of indices within the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.AllFields"></xref> collection of the fields in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.TableFields"></xref> property.
The default value is `null`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> control has not been bound to a data source or no items have been added, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.TableFieldIndices%2A> property returns `null`.
An array of integers representing the indices of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.AllFields"></xref> collection.
Gets or sets which fields are visible when the list view is shown in table mode.
The default value is an empty string ("").
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This string must be a set of identifiers, separated by semicolons.
Each identifier indicates the name or data field of the field that will be displayed.
By default, the list view is never shown in table mode unless this property is not empty.
A semicolon-delimited list of fields to be displayed when the list view is shown in table mode.
Causes tracking of view-state changes to the server control so they can be stored in the server control's <xref href="System.Web.UI.StateBag"></xref> object.
This object is accessible through the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.ViewState"></xref> property.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Gets or sets the view mode of an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The following options are available for this property through the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode> enumeration.
Member Name
Description
This is the default view displayed when the page containing the object list is rendered for the first time.

It consists of either the label fields of the items, or if the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.TableFields%2A> property is not empty, a table with columns corresponding to the table fields and rows for the items.
In HTML, this view is combined with the Commands view, with the commands appearing as hyperlinks below the list.
When there is more information in the Details view, a hyperlink for each item displaying the Details view is rendered.
In HTML, this view is combined with the Commands view, with the commands appearing as hyperlinks below the details.
This view is rendered separately only for WML devices.
It consists of a menu with the commands of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>.
For HTML devices, the List view and Details view are each combined with this view, with the commands appearing as hyperlinks below the details or list.

To set this property in code, an item in the list must be selected before setting this property to <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.Commands> or <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.Details> view.
An attempt to set the property before selecting an item throws an exception.

A view mode is persisted in a private view state, so that, regardless of whether the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> object is `true`, the view mode is persisted as a private field.
However, if the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property is `false`, the items collection is not persisted between requests, requiring a data bind to be repeated for each request.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode"></xref> value representing the view mode of the object list.
An attempt was made to set this property to a value other than <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.List"></xref> while no item was selected.
For a description of this member, see <xref href="System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler.RaisePostBackEvent(System.String)"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler> interface.
The optional event argument to be passed to the event handler.
